items.content_html:
This PR removes all <div=class="hidden"> elements from the JS documentation, except for the ones that are really part of a live sample, that are dealt with in #3718.

These are almost all boilerplate notes attached to BCD or interactive examples, although there are a few more targeted comments, that we might want to convert into HTML comments?

Assuming we do want to do this, but not in one huge PR, I can easily enough split it up into bits.
items.title: Remove hidden divs from JavaScript docs

items.content_html:
I encountered this page today, and was confused by the line

The isNaN() function determines whether a value is NaN or not. Note, coercion inside the isNaN function has interesting rules; you may alternatively want to use Number.isNaN(), as defined in ECMAScript 2015.

Due to the typography, the full stop of not. Note became almost impossible to spot. Shall we had a <div class="notecard note"> here? How would that impact the abstract for SEO? I decided to adjust the wording a bit, to not make it read like not Note.

While I was at it, I updated the code samples to drop var in favour of const.

What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

MDN URL of main page changed

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

Anything else that could help us review it
items.title: Minor edits on isNaN()

items.content_html:
createHTMLDocument always returns an HTMLDocument according to the spec.
So I changed the link to point to that documentation.

What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

The link I changed pointed to a more generic type.

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMImplementation

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

Didn't search for it.

Anything else that could help us review it
items.title: Correct link to return type

Fixes: #2667

Adds a page for the supportedEntryTypes property and the link to it from the main PerformanceObserver page.

Reviewer @jpmedley
items.title: Adds PerformanceObserver.supportedEntryTypes

items.content_html:
In the examples in the JavaScript “static” article, the class names (e.g., Triple, BiggerTriple) convey their specific function — so there’s no point in giving redundant functional names to the methods; instead, let’s just use calculate() as the method name(s). And while we’re at it, let’s rename BiggerTriple to SquaredTriple — to more precisely match its specific function. Fixes #3716

And also while we’re in here, fix a macro flaw.
items.title: Use a better method name in JS “static” doc example

items.content_html: In the Types table of the “Character classes” article (documenting character classes that can be used in JavaScript regular expressions), this change adds a row for Unicode property escapes (which use the syntax \p{…} to specify Unicode character properties to match against). Fixes #3722
items.title: Link to Unicode Property Escapes from Character Classes doc

items.content_html:
This PR is related to #3694 and #3512, and it removes the only place in the JS docs where we use class="hidden" to hide part of a live sample.

I could have chosen to move hidden to the code blocks themselves, but in this case (and I expect in many other cases) think it's better not to hide them, so someone can see the whole example.

I also changed a couple of vars to let and const, and renamed the id on the <button> in the example, because <button id="btn"> was upsetting.
items.title: Unhide code blocks in live sample for Promise

items.content_html:
Working on #3455 this PR:

  1. Moves the non-standard :-moz-ui-valid to :user-valid
  2. Updates that page to be correct as to the spec, adds an example
  3. Updates user-invalid as it still referred to the moz property it was moved from
  4. Adds an example to user-invalid

I'm next going to do the BCD and syntax entries for the pseudo, which currently will show as an error.
items.title: updating user-valid and user-invalid

items.content_html: This change makes some refinements to the “A re-introduction to JavaScript (JS tutorial)” article to flesh out the information about anonymous functions and IIFEs. Fixes #3553
items.title: Improve JS docs on anonymous functions and IIFEs
Added paragraph "Naming conventions" (simple addition)
